citeinfo.title: Cenozoic Sedimentary and Tectonic History of the Bering Sea

abstract.p: The Bering Sea consists of an abyssal basin that became isolated from the Pacific Ocean by the development of the Aleutian Ridge near the end Cretaceous time and by formation of the large epicontinental shelf area that first became submerged near the middle of the Tertiary Period.

[Reference: Nelson, C.H., Hopkins, D.M., and Scholl, D.W., 1974, Cenozoic sedimentary and tectonic history of the Bering Sea, in Hood, D.W., and Kelley, E.J., eds., Oceanography of the Bering Sea with emphasis on renewable resources, Part 7, Geological processes: Fairbanks, University of Alaska Institute of Marine Science Occasional Publication no.2, p. 485-516.]

descript.purpose: To collect and record data of Cenozoic sedimentary and tectonic history of the Bering Sea.
